byline.contributor: Ellen Barry reported from Katmandu, and Nida Najar from New Delhi. Tom Mashberg contributed reporting from Boston, and Somini Sengupta from the United Nations.
byline.original: By ELLEN BARRY and NIDA NAJAR

abstract: Officials in Nepal are taking steps to prevent looting of artifacts and pieces from historic sites damaged in massive earthquake, concern largely ignored in first days after disaster because of urgent need to rescue survivors; delay in addressing preservation of centuries-old sites has led to sense of helplessness in face of devastation, reducing chances that one of largest clusters of cultural heritage sites in world can be rebuilt.
lead_paragraph: In many places, the detritus of centuries-old temples and palaces has been left unguarded, diminishing chances to eventually rebuild one of the world’s largest clusters of cultural heritage sites.

headline.main: Nepal’s Cultural Heritage Becomes Its Scrap as Human Crisis Takes Priority After Earthquake
headline.print_headline: Human Crisis in Nepal Fuels a Cultural One

snippet: In many places, the detritus of centuries-old temples and palaces has been left unguarded, diminishing chances to eventually rebuild one of the world’s largest clusters of cultural heritage sites.

keywords.value: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
